Award.AwardTitle: Efficient Strategies for Pandemic Monitoring and Recovery

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
In the absence of effective vaccines or treatments, social distancing has been shown to be effective in controlling the initial spread of a pandemic. While the decision on when to start social distancing can be based on the occurrence of a few positive test cases, the decision on when to ease such measures during pandemic recovery is considerably more difficult due to the possibility of a second wave. Our goal in this project is to develop new artificial intelligence (AI) algorithms to support this decision-making, by making more efficient use of limited test availability and also drawing on novel data sources (and physical models) not limited by testing. The research will be divided into two inter-related thrusts. The first thrust in on efficient ways to determine the status of individuals in the community through new AI based methods for group testing. The second thrust is focused on community level pandemic assessment using a data-driven quickest change detection (QCD) framework.

The project, if successful, will have a direct and obvious impact on pandemic recovery, for COVID-19 and future pandemics. This will in turn have significant social and economic impacts. The goal is to rapidly deploy research results via relationships in government and industry. Broader impact activities include: navigating the ethical tradeoff between equity and accuracy in group testing designs; supporting a diverse cohort of undergraduate researchers in this topical area; developing a new, general educational module for laboratory-based data science classes (at Illinois and around the world); integrating diversity by training a diverse cohort of graduate students; and public outreach via established media presence.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Without effective vaccines or treatments, social distancing has been effective in controlling contagions, epidemics, and pandemics.  While starting social distancing may follow some positive cases, the decision to ease such measures is considerably more difficult due to the possibility of further spread. Our project developed new insights and algorithms to support this decision-making. The research focused on efficient ways to determine the status of individuals through new methods for group testing, which were generalized to broader mathematical results on efficient use of resources in numerous settings with economies of scale. The research developed new characterizations of epidemic extinction in the face of interventions.  The project further focused on community-level pandemic assessment using a data-driven quickest change detection (QCD) framework, yielding more general mathematical results. Finally, the research used causal inference to empirically study the impacts of social distancing during the COVID-19 pandemic, not just on the disease itself, but also on mental health, which is another important factor.  Social determinants of various COVID-19 interventions (including social distancing) were also studied using causal inference.  The research further developed novel econometric methods for causal inference and policy design, which can be used in several social and health settings.

Group testing minimizes the cost of testing a large batch of samples by pooling them together. When samples arrive over time rather than being available at the same time, there is generally a waiting cost in letting many samples accumulate. However, testing too soon leads to a large testing cost by missing the benefits of pooling. Considering the problem of both minimizing the average wait time and the testing cost, we developed online algorithms that approach the performance of a lower bound we developed that no online algorithm can beat. We further generalized this formulation to consider any queuing setting with economies of scale, which has applications throughout operations research, communication systems, and elsewhere.

To study the extinction of epidemics, we developed a model where the per-person infectiousness in a network of geographic localities changes with the total number of active cases, as people adopt more stringent social distancing when the population has a larger number of active cases. We showed there is a sharp threshold such that when the curing rate for the infection is above this threshold, the expected time for the epidemic to die out is logarithmic in the initial infection size, whereas when the curing rate is below this threshold, the expected time for epidemic extinction is infinite. We further demonstrated that if the per-person infectiousness is large when the epidemic size is small (i.e., precautions are lax when the epidemic is small and only get stringent after the epidemic has become large), it might take a very long time for the epidemic to die out.

To expeditiously inform the decision to lift social distancing (based on epidemic statistics changing), we developed several new results in quickest change detection.  These settings include quickest change detection with controlled sensing, for data-driven distributionally robustness, with post-change density estimation, and under high-probability/low-latency settings.  Collectively, these results provide insights into a variety of information patterns and societal criteria.

Social distancing, face masking, and vaccination have all been essential in controlling contagion, but were not uniformly adopted by communities in the United States during the COVID-19 pandemic. We used different facets of social capital to causally explain the differences in public behaviors among communities. We further showed that lockdowns caused significant increase in usage of mental health facilities in regions with lockdowns, compared to regions without lockdowns. Resource usage increased by 18% in regions with a lockdown compared to 1% decline in regions without a lockdown. Female populations had a larger lockdown effect.  These insights inform other important factors for policymakers to impose/lift social distancing.  Within our work on causal inference, we developed a new deterministic approach that provides policy evaluators with both "worst-case" outcomes and "typical" outcomes to help in decision making, and an approach to designing optimal discontinuities in policymaking.

For part of the period of performance, the Co-PI was on leave to serve on the National Security Council staff in the Executive Office of the President (White House).  Through this avenue, policymakers in the biosecurity directorate of the National Security Council and the pandemic preparedness team in the Office of Science and Technology Policy (OSTP), both in the White House, were engaged on the topic of the project’s research.  As such, there was impact from research on national policymaking.  The project led to the training of several graduate students, and research work was presented at public science events with tens of thousands of participants. Some work on social capital and epidemic mitigation appeared in the popular media.  A workshop on AI+Health was organized in Chicago with participation from throughout the region and the world.
